newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ debt ends weaker on lower TWI, Brash comments.
newsitem.headline: NZ debt ends weaker on lower TWI, Brash comments.

text.p: Figures in brackets compare against previous day's close
FUTURES PHYSICAL YIELD (PCT)
90-DAY BILLS (JUN) 92.86 (PREV 92.96) 90-DAYS 6.89 (PREV 6.78)
OVERNIGHT CASH 6.00 PCT (PREV 6.10) US 5-YR 6.55 (PREV 6.53)
* NZ yields finish higher as currency slips
* RBNZ's Brash dampens sentiment through cautious remarks
* High volumes trade
New Zealand debt ended weaker across the curve on Wednesday after a bad start on the back of a lower currency.
Dealers said the market's tone never really recovered, and the market's recent easing was arrested by comments made by Reserve Bank governor Don Brash.

The currency ended down at 67.94 on its Trade-Weighted Index, from 68.19 at Tuesday's close and 67.92 at today's open. Dealers said more than NZ$300 million of kiwi was dumped onto the market overnight, prompting an initial round of selling as the forex market opened.
In response to the lower TWI the 90-day bill rates climbed to 6.87 percent in early trade, and notched up another couple of basis points during the session to end at 6.89 percent.
The June futures contract finished 10 points weaker at 92.86 on solid volume of 4,658 contracts.
The RBNZ's Brash, appearing before parliament's Finance and Expenditure Committee, failed to give the market reassurance that its recent easing in monetary conditions was appropriate.
The market read comments by Brash last week as indicating the central bank would take an easier stance on conditions in its June monetary policy statement.
In March it signalled it preferred 90-days at 7.5 percent and the TWI at 68.0, or an equivalent mix.
"At this stage we have to say that we haven't changed our desired monetary conditions from those announced in the middle of March," Brash said.
Dealers said the Brash's taciturn stance had compounded the negative tone shrouding the market.
"He's not promising anything, which is very him," one said.
The dealer said short rates had recently pushed down to levels where downside was limited, and people started seeing scope for profit-taking after Brash's comments and on the weak TWI.
Trade was whippy in the futures market while the physicals were more calm, although a move lower in cash to six percent prompted some buying in the 30-day bank bills.
-- Catherine McCaw, Wellington newsroom (64 4) 471 4275
